awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research:  Helical Protein Assemblies by Design
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Molecular self-assembly is a fundamental principle of life, with cells having mastered this process to encode incredible diversity of function. Helical protein assemblies organize much of the intracellular and extracellular structure, and direct all movement. The ability to emulate such functions by designing synthetic protein assemblies would transform modern molecular science, with far-reaching applications including locomotion, controlled release, directional transport, dynamic switching, and shape-selective catalysis. However, structurally ordered supramolecular materials on the nanometer length-scale are the most challenging to rationally construct and the most difficult to structurally analyze. The size and structural complexity of these extended protein assemblies present a significant challenge to current computational design methods. The rules that govern protein-protein interactions are more complex and difficult to reliably predict than for DNA. In this project, a novel intellectual framework for the targeted design of synthetic protein assemblies at atomic-level accuracy will be established, validated, and made available to the research community. Enabled by the combined expertise of the three investigators involved, this approach will merge significant advances in modeling and computational design with never-before-possible experimental techniques for structural determination of protein assemblies at the atomic level. On the way to developing this framework, fundamental questions of acute significance to biology, chemistry, and materials science will be addressed: from development of an understanding of the functional roles of native biological assemblies to construction of synthetic assemblies for technological applications. Students (graduate and undergraduate), postdoctorals, and faculty involved in this project will gain experience in a variety of computational, synthetic, and analytical methods in research areas of fundamental technological interest that will prepare them well for future scientific careers. An exchange program between the three academic institutions (Emory University, University of Virginia, and Dartmouth College) will be established that will permit students and postdoctorals to become involved in the different aspects of this research project.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Helical protein assemblies in biological systems exhibit a rich portfolio of structure and function; capturing these within simpler and more tractable synthetic materials would amount to a major leap in molecular science. Recent technological advances in genome sequencing, bioinformatic analysis, near-atomic resolution cryo-EM structural determination, and computational protein design, in combination with extant synthetic and analytical methods, present an unprecedented opportunity to engineer novel protein assemblies that emulate and improve upon their native counter-parts. This project will employ protein designability, estimated on the basis of native structural representation, as a mechanism to promote and control association between folded protein motifs with an aim to create protein-based materials of defined structure and function. Designability in the context of protein engineering refers to robustness of a protein fold in sequence space. A proxy for designability is the frequency of occurrence of a structural motif within the Protein Data Bank (PDB). This approach will be employed to search for designable interfaces between protomers within the protein structural databank. The ultimate objective of the proposed research will be to define sequences based on simple secondary or tertiary structural elements that are competent for self-assembly into nano-scale materials with extended helical symmetry. Computational methods will be employed to interrogate the protein structural databank to identify designable interfaces within robust structural motifs. Suitable candidate sequences will be computationally optimized and synthesized. Proven biophysical methods will be employed initially to identify sequences with promising self-assembly behavior. State-of-the-art high-resolution structural analyses will be performed on these assemblies using Iterative Helical Real-Space Reconstruction (IHRSR) from cryo-EM images. Dramatic improvements in imaging hardware, reconstruction algorithms, and computational methods of structural refinement have provided rapid access to near-atomic resolution structures of native and synthetic helical assemblies. These analyses will inform future rounds of computational modeling and design, thus establishing a dynamic feedback loop between theory, synthesis, and advanced methods of structural analysis.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are the workhorse molecules of life. These polymers of amino-acid building blocks are what our genomic DNA codes for. Once produced by the cellular machinery, proteins go on to perform an incredible variety of tasks in a precise and accurate manner—from catalyzing bespoke chemical reactions, to detecting external stimuli such as chemicals or light, to converting energy into mechanical force—proteins do it all. Given the incredible functional capacity of this class of molecules, considerable interest exists in learning to engineer custom proteins for custom and precise molecular tasks. Because proteins achieve their function by folding into specific three-dimensional shapes, a key problem is to learn to design proteins that fold into pre-specified shapes.

The goal of this project was to develop computational and experimental tools towards designing proteins that not only fold on their own, but also further interact with one another to assemble into precise helical shapes (known as helical assemblies). This work was a collaboration between two labs—the Grigoryan lab at Dartmouth College worked on computational methods for design and the Conticello lab at Emory University developed experimental techniques for producing designed proteins and ascertaining their assemblies. While the initial scope of the work was limited to helical assemblies only, as the methods matured and experimental validation emerged, we realized that our results had implications for general-purpose methods of computational protein design of arbitrary targets. 

Our approaches relied on the concept of TERMs or “tertiary motifs”—fragments of protein three-dimensional structures that occur frequently among unrelated proteins. TERMs can be thought of as a shape alphabet that proteins can achieve by varying their amino-acid sequence, and by collecting all TERMs from a large database of known protein structures we learned a great deal about how amino-acid sequence and three-dimensional structure are related. The initial work showing this was published in MacKenzie, Zhou, Grigoryan, PNAS, 113, 2016.

Knowing the sequence-structure rules inherent in TERMs, we developed computational methods that could propose novel protein structures that could assemble into desired helical shapes. But we were also able to develop a general-purpose method for designing arbitrary-shaped proteins. In particular, once a shape was specified, the method broke it up into its constituent TERMs and mined the database of known protein structures for information on amino-acid sequences that were needed to satisfy each motif. This information was then combined to produce sequences that were predicted to fold to the specified shape. The method, which we dubbed dTERMen, worked quite well and was validated in a number of different systems [2-4].

In all, the Grigoryan lab published 11 papers resulting from this work (see below). The work also had a broader impact on training of young scientists. In particular, this project employed the efforts of multiple graduate, undergraduate, and post-doctoral researchers in a cross-cutting initiative that focuses on research at the interface between materials science and biology (2 PhD students, 2 undergraduate students, and 1 post-doc at the Grigoryan lab). These researchers gained insight into the various aspects of the work as conducted at the collaborating institutions. A PhD student in the Conticello lab participated in a researcher exchange program, spending time in the Grigoryan lab to broaden their knowledge of computational methods.

Some of the published work by the Grigoryan lab emerging from this project:

1.     "A C++ library for protein sub-structure search", J. Zhou, G. Grigoryan, bioRxiv, 2020.

2.     "A general-purpose protein design framework based on mining sequence-structure relationships in known protein structures", J. Zhou, A. E. Panaitiu, G. Grigoryan, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 117(2): 1059-1068, 2019.

3.     "Dissociating STAT4 and STAT5 Signaling Inhibitory Functions of SOCS3: Effects on CD8 T Cell Responses", J. Y. Hwang, J. E. Holland, K. B. Valenteros, Y. Sun, Y. K. Usherwood, A. F. Verissimo, J. S. McLellan, G. Grigoryan, E. J. Usherwood, ImmunoHorizons, 3(11): 547-558, 2019.

4.     "Tertiary structural motif sequence statistics enable facile prediction and design of peptides that bind anti-apoptotic Bfl-1 and Mcl-1", V. Frappier, J. M. Jenson, J. Zhou, G. Grigoryan, A. E. Keating, Structure, 27(4): 606-617, 2019.

5.     "Contact prediction is hardest for the most informative contacts, but improves with the incorporation of contact potentials", J. Holland, Q. Pan, G. Grigoryan, PLoS ONE, 13(6): e0199585, 2018.

6.     "Sequence statistics of tertiary structural motifs reflect protein stability", F. Zheng, G. Grigoryan*, PLoS ONE, 12(5): e0178272, 2017.

7.     "Protein Structural Motifs in Prediction and Design", C. O. Mackenzie, G. Grigoryan*, Current Opinion in Structural Biology, 44: 161-167, 2017.

8.     "The accommodation index measures the perturbation associated with insertions and deletions in coiled-coils: Application to understand signaling in histidine kinases", N. W. Schmidt, G. Grigoryan, W. F. DeGrado, Protein Science, 26(3): 414-435, 2017.

9.     "Tertiary Alphabet for the Observable Protein Structural Universe", C. O. Mackenzie, J. Zhou, G. Grigoryan*, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 113(47): E7438-E7447, 2016.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2021
Modified by: Gevorg Grigoryan
